PCI.ENDPOS: Arthur F. and Mary J. O'Neil Director of the Fanning Center for Business Communication
PCI.BIO: James S. O'Rourke teaches management and corporate communication, as well as business writing and speaking, at the University of Notre Dame, where he is a Teaching Professor of Management and the Arthur F. and Mary J. O'Neil Director of the Fanning Center for Business Communication. He earned a BBA in Management from Notre Dame, an MS in Mass Communication from Temple University, an MA in Speech Communication from the University of New Mexico, and a Ph.D. in Public Communication from Syracuse University. He is the author of 17 prominent textbooks, including Management Communication (5/e Prentice Hall) and The Truth About Confident Presenting (Financial Times). He is principal author or directing editor of more than 250 case studies in management and corporate communication. O'Rourke is a trustee of both the Arthur W. Page Society and the Institute for Public Relations. He is a member of the Reputation Institute and the Management Communication Association, and a regular consultant to Fortune 500 and mid-size businesses throughout North America.

PASTHIST.TITLE: Teaching Professor of Management
PASTHIST.DESC: From 1990 to the present, founding director of the Eugene D. Fanning Center for Business Communication. Instructs both graduate and undergraduate students.

PASTHIST.TITLE: Lieutenant Colonel, USAF
PASTHIST.DESC: Served as a commissioned officer in the United States Air Force from 1970-1990. Military decorations include Meritorious Service Medal, Joint Service Commendation Medal, Air Force Commendation Medal, and others.

AWARDHONOR.NAME: The Arthur W. Page Case Writing Prize
AWARDHONOR.DESC: Honored as directing editor and faculty sponsor for two student-written case studies in the Arthur W. Page Society Case-Writing Competition in Corporate Communication. Two separate case studies were honored with second and third place in the business schools category.

AWARDHONOR.NAME: The Arthur W. Page Case Writing Prize
AWARDHONOR.DESC: Honored as directing editor and faculty sponsor of student case-writers in the Arthur W. Page Society Case Writing Competition in Corporate Communication. Separate cases were honored with first, second, and third place in the business schools category.

AWARDHONOR.NAME: Distinguished Publication on Business Communication
AWARDHONOR.DESC: The Association for Business Communication designated my textbook, "Management Communication: A Case-Analysis Approach" (Prentice Hall: 2010) as "Distinguished Publication on Business Communication for 2010". The award was presented at the 75th Annual ABC Convention on October 29, 2010 in Chicago, Illinois.

AWARDHONOR.NAME: The Arthur W. Page Case Writing Prize
AWARDHONOR.DESC: Grand Prize, 2010. First Place, Business Schools Category, 2010. Second Place, Business Schools Category, 2010.

AWARDHONOR.NAME: Arthur F. and Mary's J. O'Neil Director of the Fanning Center for Business Communication
AWARDHONOR.DESC: Named as an endowed director of the Eugene D. Fanning Center for Business Communication. Director of the Center since August 1990. Appointed to endowed chair in May 2007.

AWARDHONOR.NAME: The Arthur W. Page Case Writing Prize
AWARDHONOR.DESC: Grand Prize, 2007. First Place, Business Schools Category, 2007.

AWARDHONOR.NAME: The Arthur W. Page Case Writing Prize
AWARDHONOR.DESC: Second Place, Business Schools Category, 2006. Third Place, Business Schools Category, 2006.

AWARDHONOR.NAME: The Arthur W. Page Case Writing Prize
John A. Kaneb Award for Excellence in Undergraduate Teaching
AWARDHONOR.DESC: University of Notre Dame award acknowledging suprior teaching skills among faculty who have taught undergraduate students for five years or more.

AWARDHONOR.NAME: The Arthur W. Page Case Writing Prize
AWARDHONOR.DESC: Grand Prize, 2003; Second Place, Crisis or Issues Management.

AWARDHONOR.NAME: The Arthur W. Page Case Writing Prize
Gannett Foundation Teaching Fellow
AWARDHONOR.DESC: The Gannett Foundation annually selects two dozen journalism and communication educators to study at Indiana University, Bloomington to broaden and enrich their skillset.

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Ten Years Hence: A Lecture Series

In workshop fashion, we are preparing them for presentations of their science and technology developments as they craft a viable business plan.

OFF_LOAD_TEACH.TITLE: Digital Media Strategy: The Case of MTV Networks
OFF_LOAD_TEACH.PEDINN: This deep-dive course focuses on digital media and corporate strategy with a particular interest in a new MTV digital platform, schedule for rollout in July 2010. Students are asked to devise a strategy for the company and its new product.

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Putting Reputation at Risk: The Seven Factors of Reputational Management. In O. Williams (ed.), Sustainable Development: The UN Millennium Development Goals, The UN Global Compact, and the Common Good.
Teaching Strategic Communication in Business Schools: New Evidence from the C-Suite
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: A survey of Fortune 500 firms, combined with personal interviews of selected C-Suite executives underscores the value of Strategic Communication as a curricular offering in both undergraduate and graduate schools of business.

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Management Communication: A Case-Analysis Approach, 5/e
Corporate Reputation and the Discipline of Management Communication. In C. Carroll (Ed.) Handbook of Communication and Corporate Reputation
BP and the Gulf Oil Spill (A)
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: An April 20, 2010 explosion on board the Deepwater Horizon offshore oil-drilling platform killed 11 workers, injured 17 and triggered a leak that spilled more than 206 million gallons of oil over 665 miles of coastline and 4,000 square miles of fishing waters. This case discusses the events that led to the disaster and oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. It also outlines key figures within BP's organization and how they factored into the long and difficult corporate communications process.

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Carnival Cruise Lines: Fire Aboard a Stranded Cruise Ship
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: In the early morning hours of November 8, 2010, fire broke out in the aft engine room of Carnival Splendor, a 113,300 ton passenger cruise ship carrying over 3,000 guests. Although the fire was quickly suppressed, Cruise Director John Heald and the ship's crew found themselves stranded in the Pacific Ocean, 200 miles south of San Diego. With no electricity, poor sanitation, and spoiling food supplies, Carnival Cruise Lines must determine how best to manage this unforeseen event and ensure the safety of those onboard. This crisis management case exposes the reader to the decision-making and communication challenges faced by senior leaders in the tumultous environment following such a crisis.

INTELLCONT.PUBLISHER: Dorling Kindersley: The Penguin Group, Ltd.
INTELLCONT.TITLE: Effective Communication
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: A part of DK's "Essential Managers" trade book series, this title features 34 brief chapters that provide a broad overview of management communication in an organizational setting.

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Management Communication: A Case-Analysis Approach, 4/e
Graphics and Visual Communication for Managers
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: A comprehensive review of the basics of visual and graphic theory, combined with current best practices in management communication.

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Intercultural Communication for Business
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: Sixth in an eight-volume series on Managerial Communication. Prof. O'Rourke serves as editor of the series

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Interpersonal Communication: Listening and Responding
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: Seventh in an eight-volume series on Managerial Communication. Prof. O'Rourke serves as editor of the series.

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Leading Groups and Teams

INTELLCONT.TITLE: The Truth About Confident Presenting
Beginning Your Career Search
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: A hands-on approach to building a career portfolio.

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Management Communication: A Case-Analysis Approach, 3/e
The Business Communication Casebook: A Notre Dame Collection, 2/e
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: A collection of 37 original case studies in business and corporate communication. Key topics include brand image and identity, crisis management, financial services, international and intercultural communication, pharmaceutical, and transportation. Each case is accompanied by a teaching note and powerpoint file (available online). ISBN: 978-0-324-54509-8.

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Google in China: Government Censorship and Corporate Reputation
Merck & Co. Inc.: Communication Lessons from the Withdrawl of Vioxx
Managing Conflict and Workplace Relationships

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Management Communication: A Case-Analysis Approach, 2/e
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: This is the second edition of a text on Management Communication aimed at first-year MBA candidates. The central feature of the book is a series of case studies designed to engage students in authentic communication issues and activities

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, Inc.: The Fall of an American Icon
Beginning Your Career Search: A Hands-on Approach to Building Your Career Portfolio, 3/e
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: This is the third edition of a book aimed at upper-division undergraduates, providing practical advice and authentic examples of resume format, employment correspondence, and career portfolio elements

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Communication in a Virtual Organization
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: Third in an eight-volume series on Managerial Communication. Prof. O'Rourke serves as editor of the series

INTELLCONT.TITLE: e-Technology and the Fourth Economy
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: Second in an eight-volume series on Managerial Communication. Prof. O'Rourke serves as series editor.

INTELLCONT.TITLE: The Art of Downsizing: Communicating Layoffs to Key Stakeholders
The Business Communication Casebook: A Notre Dame Collection, 1/e
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: A collection of 36 original management and business communication case studies written by Mendoza College of Business MBA Candidates. Each comes with a Teaching Note and PowerPoint file; many come with (B) cases

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc. and Ford Motor Company: How a Product Safety Crisis Ended a Hundred-Year Relationship
Business Communication: A Framework for Success
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: A comprehensive textbook aimed at upper- division undergraduate business students. Focuses on writing, speaking, and communication applications in organizations large and small

INTELLCONT.TITLE: American Electrical, Inc.: Managing an Environmental Crisis

CONSULT.DESC: I assisted Joanne Bischmann, Vice President for Communications at Harley-Davidson with a structural reorganization of her global comms team. Work streams, reporting lines, accountability, productivity measures, and more were considered. A new organization chart and new lines of accountability resulted.
Consulted with Milwaukee law firm Quarles & Brady LLP on the design of a training program that would incorporate case studies to improve critical thinking and communication skills.
Consulted with AM General Corporation on the design and delivery of an executive speech training program intended to improve presentation skills.

FACDEV.TITLE: Tuck School Academic Symposium on Corporate Communication
FACDEV.ORG: The Arthur W. Page Society, The Tuck School at Dartmouth, and the Institute for Public Relations
FACDEV.DESC: The Tuck School Academic Symposium, held May 21-23, 2007 at Dartmouth College, examined a wide range of contemporary issues facing corporate communication and public relations professionals, including business educators.
